Award.AwardTitle: Topology, geometry and arithmetic of hyperbolic 3-manifolds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Culler and Shalen will continue their research on hyperbolic 3-manifolds. One of the main themes of their work is the connection between topologically defined invariants of such manifolds and their quantitative geometric invariants such as volume. This has involved interactions between very classical techniques in 3-manifold topology, some of which go back to Papakyriakopoulos's work in the 1950's, and more geometric methods such as the log(2k-1)-theorem of Anderson, Canary, Culler and Shalen, the work of Kojima and Miyamoto on hyperbolic manifolds with totally geodesic boundary, and the work of Agol, Dunfield, Storm and Thurston based on properties of the Ricci flow with surgeries. A second theme, which recently has grown out of the first, is the connection between the number-theoretic invariants of a manifold such as its trace field and quantitative geometric invariants such as its Margulis number. This aspect of the work depends on combining the earlier work with new group-theoretic observations, and has already brought into play such deep number-theoretic ingredients as the work of Siegel and Mahler on the unit equation in algebraic number fields.

Hyperbolic manifolds are geometric objects that arise in many branches of mathematics and in many applications of mathematics. The first hyperbolic manifold, called hyperbolic space, was discovered in the 19th century and settled---in the negative---the ancient problem of whether Euclid's fifth postulate could be deduced from his other postulates. Hyperbolic manifolds may be thought of as geometric objects which at small scales are indistinguishable from hyperbolic space, but whose large-scale behavior is more complicated. A major theme in modern geometry is the interaction between the quantitative properties of a geometric object, for example those defined in terms of distances, lengths, areas and volumes, and their "topological"
properties which are more qualitative and are unchanged when the object is deformed. In the case of hyperbolic manifolds, so much progress has been made in recent years in relating the quantitative and topological theories that they may be said to be completely unified at an abstract level. The present project involves making our understanding the connection in a more concrete way. Doing this turns out to involve deep ideas from many branches of mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the remarkable trends in mathematical research over the last 50 years is the discovery of connections among branches of mathematics that had traditionally been independent of one another. The area of research known as hyperbolic geometry has provided a striking example of this. The field had its origins in the discovery, during the 19th century, that the ancient problem of deducing Euclid's parallel postulate from his other axioms could not be solved, because there is a geometric system, called hyperbolic space, that satisfies all of Euclid's other axioms, but in which the parallel postulate fails to hold. In this system, the sum of the angles of a triangle is always less than 180 degrees. During the course of the 20th century, geometric objects called hyperbolic manifolds came to be studied; these are spaces which on a small scale resemble hyperbolic space, but on a large scale have a more complicated structure. It became clear that these objects play a central role in many areas of the most active areas of mathematical research, including the theory of numbers, differential geometry, and geometric group theory. On the other hand, the groundbreaking work of Mostow, Thurston and Perelman established astonishingly close links, in three dimensions, between geometry of hyperbolic manifolds on the one hand and another research area known as topology on the other. In topology one studies most basic qualitiative properties of geometric objects, those that can be expressed purely in terms of continuity rather than involving distances, volumes or angles. Although the geometry of hyperbolic manifolds, which is quantitative in the same way that Euclidean geometry is, seems on the face of it to be radically different from topology, the results due to Mostow, Thurston and Perelman show that in an abstract sense, the theory of hyperbolic manifolds is completely equivalent, in the three-dimensional case, to the theory of the purely topological objects known as smooth manifolds.

The problem addressed by the research done under this grant is to make the equivalence between these two theories explicit. Topologists have long studied smooth manifolds by associating certain numerical quantities with them, that are defined in a purely topological way. For example, a 2-dimensional smooth manifold, if it satisfies simple conditions called orientability, connectedness and compactness, can always be realized as the surface of a doughnut with some number of holes; this number of holes is called the genus of the 2-manifold. One challenge presented by the abstract results of Mostow, Thurston and Perelman is to understand explicitly the relationship between topologically defined quantities associated to 3-manifolds, similar to the genus of a 2-manifold, and geometrically defined quantities such as volume and diameter. A great many such relationships have been found in the work supported by this grant. To cite a single example, if the volume of a hyperbolic 3-manifold is at most 3.44, a quantity called the mod 2 first betti number of the manifold is at most 7. The mod 2 first betti number is a topologically defined quantity that can be associated with any smooth manifold; for example, in the case of a (compact, connected, orientable) 2-manifold it is twice the genus. The proof of this particular result depends on ideas developed by the investigators over a period of 20 years, and building on techniques from many different branches of mathematics.
